Really interesting Ottoman Turkish house. Houses are distinguished between houses for women and men. In this museum we can see how their lives seem to be separate, but still side by side. In one of the rooms there are various kinds of men's and women's clothes, weapons including ways to preserve food in the old riding era.
Entrance is free and the museum does give a good insight into life in the past. Only takes 20 minutes to explore, although not the best Ethnography museum that i have been to.

This museum, whose entrance is free with a museum card, is very well preserved. There are findings from various historical periods in the mansion. In this type of mansion, music that gives a pleasant Ottoman and Seljuk atmosphere can be nice in the background, and this is the only thing I can recommend for the museum. It would be nice if Turkish citizens also visit and support the museum.

It is known that Danişmentli ruler Melik Mehmed Gazi died on January 6, 1143 and was buried in the mausoleum in his own social complex.

The entrance to the tomb located on the qibla side of the grand mosque was closed. We had to visit from outside. The warning on the side of the tomb is also very meaningful. A warning was made about what might happen due to moldy bread given to pigeons.

Melik Mehmet Gazi Tomb
Melikgazi Madrasa was located in the location of this tomb, which is located to the south of Kayseri Ulu Mosque. The Tomb of Melik Mehmet Gazi was built in one of the madrasah cells adjacent to the mosque wall. This tomb belongs to Melik Mehmed Gazi, the third ruler of the Danishmends and the person who had the Ulu Mosque built.

The tomb does not have an inscription. Considering that Melik Gazi died in 1143 H. (1730), it is thought that this tomb was built on the same date. Today, the front of the tomb and the madrasah are arranged as a park.

Melikgazi Madrasa was located on the site where this tomb is located, to the south of the Kayseri Ulu Mosque. The tomb of Melik Mehmet Gazi was built next to the mosque wall in one of the madrasa cells. This tomb belongs to Melik Mehmed Gazi, the third Danischmenden ruler who built the Ulu Mosque.

This visit was part of the daily program on August 18, 2020, which we described in detail with photos in the “Kayseri tour report”.
A tomb from the 13th century. The 3rd ruler of the Danisment people who made efforts in the Islamization of Anatolia with Kayseri as the center.

There are patterns that referred Turkish symbols such as wolfs, lions and life tree. Especially, Life Tree is one of the most important symbols. Moreover, other tombs figured with religious Arabic words, while Doner Kumbet has only Turkish symbols. You should see similar/same symbols in Erzurum Çifte Minareli Medrese and Konya Seljuck tombs.
Very well restored with incredible details

The Archeological Museum in Kayseri is a great place to learn about the history of the region. You can see a lot of interesting artifacts from different periods of time.

If you're interested in ancient history, you should definitely check out the Archeological Museum in Kayseri. It's a great place to learn about the different civilizations that inhabited the area.

It's a really fascinating museum with a lot of cool exhibits. You can see a lot of pottery, coins, and other artifacts from ancient times. There's also a lot of information about the different civilizations that have lived in the area over the centuries.

Entrance fee per january 2024 is 75TL per person.
It is a modernly designed museum with a decent size of collection. The description and story in english is accommodating, even though not as thorough as the one in Turkish. Several interactive displays are available but all in Turkish.
The highlight collection is the sarcophagus, especially the one with heracles sculpture.
Very limited souvenir option in the store.

Fantastic museum. Very well organised, lots of informative signage in english and well lit artefacts. The Neolithic statuary was a delight but there were so many interesting artefacts to admire. Well worth a visit.
Really liked this place! Exhibitions are quite rich and the museum is very nice designed. There is a lot to see, so extra info for easy-tired: there are chairs ;)
A very interesting and modern museum that covers thousand years of history of this area.The ticket is quite cheap, 12,5 TL. The museum is located in the Kayseri castle.
Don't miss the second part a short ways down the road. The guard was very informative and helped us understand what we were seeing.

This is a spot that everyone should visit. The history in this area is priceless and the access to the place is paved as well and the area is taken care of and respected by the workers. A 10/10 experience

A fantastic place! Due to the large number of clay cuneiform tablets found they are able to tell about the family living in particular houses some 4000 years back. For some houses they can tell family members names as well as business details. It seems the Assyrian traders were great record keepers. BYW - the poodle in tge name is a totally wrong translation - Kaniś was the name of the ancient city - nothing about poodle involved.

Turkish researchers examined a 4,000-year-old Assyrian tablet containing a prenuptial agreement and found out that the first infertility diagnosis was made in central Kayseri province's Kültepe district.

The clay tablet written in cuneiform script discusses infertility and a solution for the issue, which is the inability of a person to reproduce through natural means.

the clay prenuptial agreements addressed the issue of infertility in Assyrian families.
Accordingly, the wife would allow her husband to hire a hierodule - a female slave brought in to serve as a surrogate - if the couple failed to conceive a baby two years after the date of marriage.
"The female slave would be freed after giving birth to the first male baby and ensuring that the family is not be left without a child," Professor Turp said.
The tablet is on display at the Istanbul Archaeology Museum.
Assyria was a complex Mesopotamian civilization dating back to the 25th century B.C.
Kültepe was home to an Assyrian settlement of the Old Assyrian Empire from the 21st to 18th centuries B.C.
Over 1,000 cuneiform tablets were discovered at the site in 1925, while modern archaeological work started in 1948.

The director of the site, Dr. Fikri Kulakoglu, is a most excellent source of knowledge of Kültepe-Kaneš, and he leads a super group of students at the site. It was my pleasure to have been invited, and I look forward to returning!
It is a quiet park, mostly occupied by retirees, with a mosque inside, roads inside the park built, constantly cleaned by the staff, and a perfect park to relax with bird sounds.

The mosque and the tomb are side by side. The first tomb on the side of the minaret of the mosque belongs to Hasandede, and the second tomb is the joint tomb of his sons Sheikh Halil İbrahim, Sheikh Mustafa and his daughter Ümmühan Ana.

The Hacerül Esved stone was a perfect detail, and the mulberries in the garden were also very delicious. We enjoyed the treats of Grandfather Pir Hasan, accompanied by colorful roses, and the inside of the tomb was clean, it was a peaceful and beautiful environment.

Gevher Nesibe Sırahiye-Darülşifa-Hospital was built in 1206 by her brother Gıyaseddin Keyhüsrev, in accordance with the will of Gevher Nesibe, the daughter of Kılıçaslan. The fountain was built later. Like a mosque. It is estimated to be a work of the 16th or 17th century. It has been restored several times, starting from the 18th century.

This fountain, located in the south-west corner of Çifte Madrasa in Mimarsinan Park, was built in the 17th century. There is no construction inscription on the work, but there are repair inscriptions dating back to 1728 and 1871.

A very beautiful garden. It is possible to spend a special family time in its courtyards and next to its fountains. The atmosphere is very beautiful in the morning. I loved the place. At its edges there are kiosks selling snacks, candy and drinks.

It was built in 1243 by Bedreddin Muslih, the vizier of the Seljuks. It is also known as Muslihiyye Madrasa by the founder of the building, which is known as Sircali Madrasah because of its glazed brick and tile decorations. The master of the master architect, Muhammad b. Mohammed et-Tusi. In the Seljuk and Ottoman periods, Hanafi fiqh and tafsir taught madrasah XVII. century began to be devastated, demanding cells XIX. century adobe rooms were completely demolished and used until 1924. The building, which was overhauled in 1943-1954, was opened to visitors in 1960 as the Grave Monuments Section of the Konya Museum. Mahmut Akok's project was taken as a basis and restored in 1969 by the Ministry of National Education.
Nothing to see, the museum seems closed, if it existed. Just a courtyard, a tiled ewan and a carved gate, same as in other two medreses. Waist of time, and it's in an ugly delapidated district.

There is a school in the center of Teras Bünyan, with insufficient signs and a parking lot written at the entrance. You can use the school's garden or go a little further and park your car. There are 2 stores selling local products on the right of the entrance. You enter through the arched door and move forward. You buy shoe covers from where the shoe covers are located, put them on your feet and enter the glass terrace. It was built at a height of approximately 40m (I don't know the exact height). You see Pınarbaşı center in front of you. It doesn't have much of a view. If you go in the evening, the rocks are illuminated and the view becomes even more beautiful. Go and see

The area around it is nice for a picnic, but you shouldn't go there just for the glass terrace.

It is a beautiful place you should see after visiting Talas. Panaya Greek Church was restored and turned into Yaman Dede Mosque. When you go here, you can also watch the view of the city and people trying to paraglide.

Panayada, one of the largest churches of the region that has carried its historical texture from 100 years ago to the present day, unfortunately does not have the same situation in the interior, and its conversion into a mosque was not sufficient to preserve the cultural value. The importance of Kayseri citizens in stonemasonry and architecture is also evident in the church. The outdoor area and churchyard are open to visitors. Fancy plant morphs using red and basalt stones, which are abundant in the region, stand out in most areas. The most interesting thing is that the church lights are off while there are unnecessary lighting around, and it is a shame that such a valuable heritage has been left in the background. Cultural heritage belongs to the entire society…
The historical monument has not been maintained, has been left to its own devices, and has become a disgusting place, and is in a very sad state. I wish it was taken care of

the place is magnificent where you can see the canyon and the high mountains around. it’s very beautiful and narrow but just any medium size car can pass over the bridge. you feel you are in the middle of nature with the clear waterfall water and green mountains.there are not any restrooms as you are in the middle of nature but there are lots of restaurants and cafes in the area.

Went rafting, buggy driving, ziplining here with turkey Travel club and Ahmed. What a great day. A must do attraction if your staying around Antalya. Lunch provided at the end too. The water and scenery is unbelievable.

We stayed at Rio Adventure (formerly Mavi Rafting) and had the time of our life. Our lodge was facing the ancient Köpürcay River so morning time was magical! The river produces fog and we got to see the turquoise water right in front of our balcony! There are many spots with views that are more beautiful than any word can describe :)
Absolutely stunning cave spanning 350m. Quite a few steps going both up and down and dimly lit. People with limited mobility unlikely to be able to enjoy. Defo worth visiting.

This place is absolutely stunning, the water is so clear the view is wonderful and is definitely a place to see if you are visiting turkey. We planned an activity day here where we did ziplining buggy riding and water rafting. I do recommend beforehand buying waterproof shoes (crocs are okay but no trainers or flipflops) as these are necessities and the place was selling them for £10. We found shoes beforehand in Antalya and bought them for £6. You also need gloves which were expensive and you’re likely to find this cheaper elsewhere. The ziplining was super fun and the people were very kind. During the rafting, it was around 3 hours and we did get a break where you could buy food and drinks. Although our guide did not speak fluent English, we still had a lot of fun and communicated with him well enough. One important tip is to bring a change of clothes. We did not think this through and did not bring any spare clothes and we were absolutely drenched afterwards. They served lunch as part of the activities and this was chicken skewers rice salad and bread and tasted nice. I hugely recommend this place and the activities and it was so much fun definitely a highlight of my trip.
aesthetic place with a cozy cafe inside
Amazing place to see the city center evolving within and around the castle walls. It's a amazing to see time changes.

Spectacular underground city of ancient times. İt has multiple very large rooms inside, and several tunnels that stretches many kilometers each. Some of the rooms are: resting rooms, prayer rooms, dining rooms, medical treatment rooms, stock rooms and more.

I've been to many caves and underground cities, but i guess gues has been my favourite so far. Unfortunately the place is very unknown for both locals as well as foreign tourists.

Felahiye park. It has a very beautiful picnic area and view. There are camellias built by the municipality, and among the camellias there are ready-made barbecues. It is a good alternative for those looking for a picnic spot on the weekend. On the downside, they have public toilets but they are poorly used. It is a recreation area where you can have a great time with clean air and plenty of oxygen, suitable for a picnic with a perfect view, next to the Yaşar Karayel viaduct, on the edge of the Yamula dam lake, 10 km away from the Felahiye district. Very spacious and clean. The winter view is also superb.

Kızılırmak River is a river that originates from the foothills of Kızıldağ in the İmranlı district of Sivas and flows into the Black Sea in the Bafra district of Samsun. With its length of 1,355 km (841 miles), it is the longest river in Turkey that originates within its borders and flows into the sea within its borders. Passing through the provinces of Sivas, Kayseri, Nevşehir, Kırşehir, Kırıkkale, Ankara, Çankırı, Çorum, Sinop and Samsun, Kızılırmak collects the waters of many rivers and streams such as Delice River, Devrez and Gökırmak and draws a large curve from Bafra Cape to the Black Sea. reaches.

Small parking slot available at the end of terrace, which is not sufficient. Most of cars parked on a right side of the road.
I liked this zoo a lot! No visitors at all, tiny price (25 tl for a person), huge cells! and open fenced areas! for animals, a lake and an island, cute and healthy animals! everything is clean.

Imagine that you are going around in a zoo half of the animals are missing for a strange reason but they dint actually escape they have been gone for a while now and nobody knows why, everything seems a bit abandoned and surely in a couple of years the park will disappear.
Most likely you wont be able to find something to drink and once you go outside you will realize that you paid only 2.5 lira which is pretty cheap it's great!
The municipality supports the zoo for its citizens. Entrance is ridiculus price of € 0,14! Per adult. Children € 0,05. Good place to visist with children.

Amazing place. A wide range of animals are to be found here. Good atmosphere, very clean and constructed upon a huge area.

Much recommended.
Very cool place you will see many kind of animals

This park is an amazing escape from our busy life.
They have the cutest benches and tables for you to have a quiet picnic or hangout with your friends and family. There's also a lake in the middle.

We came here around noon and the weather was beautiful. We enjoyed our food and the scenery.  It was very relaxing.

You also get to see the Atakule tower from the garden.

Came here during winter and it was quiet as there weren't so many people around. You can access the park through the street uphill or from a path downhill. There is a pond and it appears to be dried out during the winter. There is also a structure that looks like a greenhouse but I didn't have the chance to go inside. There is an area that appeared to be an aquarium but apparently, it wasn't open when I got there. There is also an area for kids to play but it is located way uphill not in the downhill area.
Wonderful, peaceful, natural beauty ☺ Ankara Metropol City Municipality works better and keeps up this beauty by restoring the botanical area thanks to the biologists union!
Now you have the Park in its majestic aura of greenery and snaking walkways, a fountain, convenience facilities. Just overlooking the park is an enormous shopping mall.
Ice flakes in Ankara, with -3 weather, still warm to the eyes.
The greenway of the tramvay infront of the mosque is fabulous!!!
Great
Beautiful mosque in the center of Kayseri
Very old mosque next Algmhorya miydan.
Beautiful mosque

The park that Cankaya Municipality forgot and did not care about. The park where we sent messages to the municipality tens of times to repair the broken parts. 153 is the park we are looking for to receive garbage. The park we wrote on Alper Tasdel's page to build a dog playground. The park is built with our taxes but we cannot get service. I think I should change my party

It's a large park. There is a small area of ​​shade. The only thing that could be negative here are the dogs around.
Update: There are no dogs around the park these days. The doghouse at the top is also missing.
+Evenings are crowded during the summer months.

The park is very beautiful, the children have a lot of fun, but those who constantly walk in the small area prevent the children from riding their bikes and playing ball, and as if that was not enough, they also scold the children. Please find a solution.
There is a very nice park in the neighborhood, there are also sports equipment for adults.
Renovation is required, our children are in danger of falling from the railings
A picnic area with sufficiently spaced seating areas, a barbecue suitable for grilling, a magnificent view and clean air. We stayed for about an hour and left very satisfied.

June 2023
👉5⭐ facility.
👍A successful work of the municipality. Congratulations on the free public service a few kilometers away from Erciyes ski resort.
👍 I think there are 20 camellias, each with standard appearance and functionality, with a barbecue for Max 10 people, on a high ground.
👍Breakfast and meals can be organized with the fresh air and view. A special area where you can have a pleasant time with your loved ones.
👉On sunny days in June, you may catch cold in the shade, so it's better to be cautious.
👍Of course, one of the best parts is that Gelengis (Anatolian squirrels) accompany you with their families. You can feed it by hand and take beautiful photographs. You can bring a loaf of bread for them. They also love fruit.
👍Parking is available and sufficient.
👎I couldn't see a WC.
This place is worth a visit every time; the barbecue huts offer the opportunity to feast in detail. The restaurants nearby sell drinks at reasonable prices.
I know it is a suitable place for a picnic, but it was very cool in terms of coolness. It would be better if there was a toilet and sink in the picnic area.

Erciyes Mountain has a magnificent view in every way and a mesmerizing view, and the best place to watch this view is the picnic area. The roads are a little narrow due to the snow, you have to be careful, vehicles get stuck in the snow, picnickers are very helpful people immediately lend a hand. It would be great if the municipality covers the picnic camellias with transparent nylon. The wind and cold are constant.
Çobanini gave me magical feelings during my first winter Erciyes peak climbing adventure. The moonlight and calm air after Erciyes at night were priceless...

Even in August, we reached the summit at almost zero degrees on 04.08.2020. This is the place to stay for the Devil's route, but for the Ridge route, it would be better to stay in the area after following the path on the left side of the road leading to the stablization, rather than in the shepherd's den.
The 95th Erciyes summit climb of the Turkish Mountaineering Federation was held successfully on 29 October with the participation of 100 mountaineers.
It's a nice camping area, there is not always water available, you will either carry it or melt the snow depending on the season, it is very advantageous to go up the mountain from here.
The campsite is beautiful, flat, there is Metin Hoca fountain nearby.

It's amazing place! The volcano looks very impressive! You don't expect to see such a thing in Turkey. A lot of trails for different levels of riders.The main thing is to get lucky with the weather, then we'll be fine! The place is a must-see!

We visited during the summer and the cable cart was amazing. We visited the cafe up and had a beautiful view of the snow mountain.
The cable cart was not very expensive too.
The facility is hide and hard to find it by drive. But the view and the experience is sure worth it. Would love to go again in the winter to enjoy the snow and all the snow activities.

I cal highly recommend it to all types of skiërs… Very nice blue slopes, red and black slopes. Its really a top ski resort. Resturant’s and bars all over, lots of ski hiring places in the different “ski towns”. We had an amazing time. The weather was really good what helped a lot. The slopes is very well maintained as well as all the lifts. It was really a wonderful time. Would recommend it to everyone.

Lots of shops at the bottom and the restaurant at the top of the ski hill serves nice hot food. Cable car is not clean so it affected photos taken.  Didnt try other activities like the snow mobile or ski activities. No one else did too. This is a good place to just take photos and play a bit of snow with family.

Fantastic ski resort! The slopes were well-groomed, and the variety of trails catered to all skill levels. The staff was friendly and helpful, making for a seamless experience. Plus, the breathtaking mountain views added an extra touch of magic to the whole adventure. Can't wait to visit again!
Wear fly repellent on your hands and arms as you go. A swamp full of mosquitoes

I recommend you not to go in the autumn period, the water dries up. It is one of the most important bird sanctuaries of our country after Lake Abant. Its campus is large. Houses the bird miniature museum
There is nothing worth seeing, no one should go there in vain, and they charge 19 TL per person.
This is one of the rare places in our country. It contains around 300 living creatures.
Converted into worthless money

Definitely a place to visit that meets expectations. It is a fascinating place with its nature and location. It is very nice for camping, trekking etc. Hacer Strait and Yedigoller crossing route... It would be better to go with a six-high vehicle.

It has a unique land structure and it is impossible not to admire it. Never return without camping. If you are coming from Yahyalı direction, after passing the Ulupınar direction, you can come to Hacer Forests if you have a high vehicle, but the road is not only unstabilized but also very bad. If you come from here early in the morning, you can also climb the Seven Lakes. When we went, they said it was not possible to climb because it was past noon. You can get more detailed information about the area from the National park information area, located approximately 10 km after Kapuzbaşı.
The hacer forests in the Aladağlar are a visually stunning place. We were fascinated by the hacer forests we went to for offroading. It is a location you should definitely see.
This forest, which has a wide range of flora, is very suitable for camping and mountaineering activities. The kitchen part of the chalet is in ruins 🍁

There are postcard views, but not every vehicle can see it. The road is not dirt, it is stony. So if you are not careful, the tire may split. It takes about 1 hour to go up from Kapuzbaşı. There is an observation deck on the road, which has a beautiful view. The road up from here is now a stony road, it's a little difficult to go. But the view is very beautiful.

The beautiful trees planted years ago with the cooperation and diligent work of the people of Gülveren Village are now able to cool off in their shade. Thanks for everyone who has contributed efforts.
May God have mercy on Uncle Necmettin. Thanks to him, we became our recreation area.
Really great for relaxing

One of the best snowboarding experiences I’ve had in my life! The mountain is well taken care of and the lifts are in good condition. It can get confusing at times with the trails but there are few markers to help. I have struggled a little bit with the language barrier but the staff tried their best to be as helpful as possible. It was an amazing experience overall. Planning to come back here again 🤙🏼🏂
Hope to visit again with lots of powder. Take your equipment with you if you are an advanced skier
Good, affordable ski resort. The slope for beginners. And the food's prices are reasonable
Marvelous place but just I didn't like hotel's ski staffs
Very cold and an excellent place for skiing. A beautiful place to be

It used to be much nicer, but its intended use has changed over the past few years.
Guys, please be a little respectful.
The pilaf days were especially nice. Nowadays we don't even want to go. But it is a very beautiful place, it is great in the summer and the breeze is strong.
We would like to thank our municipality during the tomato paste days, it is a very good service, your father will not do what they do to you, that's all ;)

The recreation area is a nice place to go as a family. Social events, hiking and even camping can be done. Insensitive people have left the environment dirty, but the facilities are good. Fire can be lit. Picnic opportunities are nice. There are toilets and water. There is a garbage container. There is a park for children. Even the place to perform ablution is more than one. There is a lot of shade. The green area is very useful. When you get there, remember that it is the land of saints, just read it. No one will charge you for footfall. With greetings and prayers. …

It is usually crowded in the summer months, the landscaping is beautiful, it can be done for a picnic or for a walk, there is a WC, there is no parking problem, but I cannot say it is very clean, but it will do the job. LET'S KEEP THE ENVIRONMENT CLEAN, healthy days.
There are more dogs than people, they pose a danger, they need to be gathered at the dog shelter.

A nice environment to have a barbecue with your family. The only problem is stray dogs. Children and women are especially disturbed. This is the biggest problem in most recreation areas. Municipalities are not very good at this.
Nice landscape. One of the highest place in the city center. So close to visit. Should visit for sunrise. On Sundays very crowded because of picnic events. There's a little zoo as a bonus.
You can go there with your friend or family for picnic or  relaxing and fun. That place where on the hill not far from downtown. You can reach there both your own car , public trasport as well.
So good and perfect here
Best place to relax. A huge picnic area. It has a mini zoo and a clean restroom.
It’s a wonderful place with greenery, but went during holidays so it was quite smoky and smelly due to barbecues all over.
Good place for picnics. Not far from town and is easily accessible. Almost all of Kayseri could be viewed from there. Quite crowded though because its proximity to town.
Perfect for picnic and bbq with family
awesome going this place good idea :)
Good place for tracking.
Super
